Mycorrhizae form between fungi hyphae and plant roots in essentially all terrestrial plants from the simplest liverwort to the flowering angiosperm. The plant offers food & maybe shelter in return for extended foraging for nutrients, especially phosphorous. The fungus may make it possible for seedlings to survive their first season establishing roots by connecting them to fellow members of their plant species. Plant root exudates & shed leaves create the loam & rhizospere fungi live in. This may be how plants came to survive and create loam out of mineral soil particles.

Seriously though humans are only able to get dressed and eat breakfast because of other humans that did work for us to have clothing and a toothbrush and toothpaste Etc. Back in the day you had to go get your own water from a river and bring it back to your house, he had to go hunt your own food or forage for it and so much more. Life was a lot harder before humans started to have Industries where we find what we're passionate about and then learn to provide that to others. We all have gifts that can turn into products and services that expand our society to create things that in a hundred years from now we can't even dream up yet. "not every species is out for themselves"

Isn't performing these behaviours bring out for yourself? You're improving your chances of survival or the survival of your young, you could do that with an inanimate object or another animal - I think all of these examples are mutually beneficial, but helping the other species isn't the reason it's done, to each they're benefiting (out for themselves).

There aren't many examples of true altruism.
